articles.headline: Defying Others, Germany Finds Economic Success
articles.snippet: Figures reported on Friday will surely strengthen Germany’s conviction to follow its own path toward growth, in contrast to the rest of Europe.
articles.abstract: Figures reported on Friday will surely strengthen Germany’s conviction to follow its own path toward growth, in contrast to the rest of Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  Germany has sparred with its European partners over how to respond to the financial crisis, argued with the United States over the benefits of stimulus versus austerity, and defiantly pursued its own vision of how to keep its economy strong.

articles.headline: Pharmacists Take Larger Role on Health Team
articles.snippet: Drugstore pharmacists are taking on more responsibility for monitoring patients with long-term illnesses.
articles.abstract: Drugstore pharmacists are taking on more responsibility for monitoring patients with long-term illnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eloise Gelinas depends on a personal health coach.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Judge Revokes Approval of Modified Sugar Beets
articles.snippet: A federal district judge said the Agriculture Department needed to better assess the environmental consequences.
articles.abstract: A federal district judge said the Agriculture Department needed to better assess the environmental consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal district court judge revoked the government’s approval of genetically engineered sugar beets Friday, saying that the Agriculture Department had not adequately assessed the environmental consequences before approving them for commercial cultivation.

articles.headline: Obama Strongly Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site
articles.snippet: After weeks of avoiding the high-profile battle, President Obama stepped into the thorny debate, leaving little doubt about how he feels.
articles.abstract: After weeks of avoiding the high-profile battle, President Obama stepped into the thorny debate, leaving little doubt about how he feels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered a strong defense on Friday night of a proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in Manhattan, using a White House dinner celebrating Ramadan to proclaim that “as a citizen, and as president, I believe that Muslims have the same right to practice their religion as anyone else in this country.”

articles.headline: Detroit Goes From Gloom to Economic Bright Spot
articles.snippet: The excesses that hurt automakers in the past — overproduction, bloated vehicle lineups and expensive rebates — are now gone, analysts say.
articles.abstract: The excesses that hurt automakers in the past — overproduction, bloated vehicle lineups and expensive rebates — are now gone, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  After a dismal period of huge losses and deep cuts that culminated in the Obama administration’s bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, the gloom over the American auto industry is starting to lift.

articles.headline: A Decade of Wooing Wins a Harlem Store for Target
articles.snippet: Target, which opened its first Manhattan store last month, has made an ambitious effort to avoid local opposition that has hurt other big retailers.
articles.abstract: Target, which opened its first Manhattan store last month, has made an ambitious effort to avoid local opposition that has hurt other big retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Target’s first Manhattan store opened late last month in Harlem with great fanfare. The chain’s mascot, a miniature bull terrier, rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Miss New York, Doug E. Fresh and Jerry Seinfeld attended a pre-party. Crowds lined up outside the store, the largest single investment the company has made in any of its retail properties.

articles.headline: U.S. Inquiry of Drug Makers Is Widened
articles.snippet: The inquiry focuses on whether companies made illegal payments to doctors and officials in foreign countries.
articles.abstract: The inquiry focuses on whether companies made illegal payments to doctors and officials in foreign countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least a dozen major drug and device makers are under investigation by federal prosecutors and securities regulators in a broadening bribery inquiry into whether the companies made illegal payments to doctors and health officials in foreign countries.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Your Card Has Been Declined, Just as You Wanted
articles.snippet: MasterCard is about to introduce tools for credit and debit cards that let consumers block a highly customizable array of purchases.
articles.abstract: MasterCard is about to introduce tools for credit and debit cards that let consumers block a highly customizable array of purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coming soon: credit and debit cards that cut you off when you disregard your own monthly budget.

articles.headline: Real Reason for Ousting H.P.’s Chief
articles.snippet: The Hewlett-Packard board created a smoke screen to oust Mark V. Hurd when it could have fired him on legitimate grounds.
articles.abstract: The Hewlett-Packard board created a smoke screen to oust Mark V. Hurd when it could have fired him on legitimate grounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The resignation of Mark V. Hurd last week from his seemingly secure post as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard has got to be one of the great head-scratchers in recent times.

articles.headline: A Battle in Mining Country Pits Coal Against Wind
articles.snippet: Opponents of mountaintop mining have proposed an alternative in West Virginia: a wind farm they say could save the land and diversify employment.
articles.abstract: Opponents of mountaintop mining have proposed an alternative in West Virginia: a wind farm they say could save the land and diversify employment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCK CREEK, W.Va.

articles.headline: Hey, Archie! Want to Build an Empire?
articles.snippet: A new management team is aggressively trying to transform the Archie family of characters into global brands in comics, film and apparel.
articles.abstract: A new management team is aggressively trying to transform the Archie family of characters into global brands in comics, film and apparel.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAS Archie Andrews “gone wild”?

articles.headline: Secret Assault on Terrorism Widens on Two Continents
articles.snippet: In a dozen countries — including in North Africa, Pakistan and former Soviet republics — the United States has significantly increased military and intelligence operations.
articles.abstract: In a dozen countries — including in North Africa, Pakistan and former Soviet republics — the United States has significantly increased military and intelligence operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Scott Shane, Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Japan, Checking on Its Oldest, Finds Many Gone
articles.snippet: Revelations of missing centenarians have hit an aging population already grappling with caring for the elderly.
articles.abstract: Revelations of missing centenarians have hit an aging population already grappling with caring for the elderly.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan has long boasted of having many of the world’s oldest people  testament, many here say, to a society with a superior diet and a commitment to its elderly that is unrivaled in the West.

articles.headline: Voter Anger No Surprise to Democrats This Time
articles.snippet: Among the advantages Republicans hold as they seek to control Congress, one thing is missing: surprise. Unlike in 1994, there will be no sneak attacks.
articles.abstract: Among the advantages Republicans hold as they seek to control Congress, one thing is missing: surprise. Unlike in 1994, there will be no sneak attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVADA, Mo.  A year ago, dozens of protesters gathered outside the district office of Representative Ike Skelton, a Democrat who has represented a wide stretch of western Missouri since 1976. The anger they directed at health care legislation  and by extension most Congressional Democrats  left the party in a state of near panic.

articles.headline: In This Play, One Role Is Enough
articles.snippet: A congressman wants to eliminate the dual roles played by big mortgage servicers.
articles.abstract: A congressman wants to eliminate the dual roles played by big mortgage servicers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEET Brad Miller, a Democratic representative from North Carolina who was elected to Congress in 2002, talks straight and understands how big banks can put consumers at peril.

articles.headline: Scissors, Glue, Pencils? Check. Cleaning Spray?
articles.snippet: With school budgets shrinking, parents are asked to provide cleaning products as well as crayons and scissors.
articles.abstract: With school budgets shrinking, parents are asked to provide cleaning products as well as crayons and scissors.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Emily Cooper headed off to first grade in Moody, Ala., last week, she was prepared with all the stuff on her elementary school’s must-bring list: two double rolls of paper towels, three packages of Clorox wipes, three boxes of baby wipes, two boxes of garbage bags, liquid soap, Kleenex and Ziplocs.

articles.headline: Petraeus Opposes a Rapid Pullout in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The commander of American and NATO forces said he did not come to Afghanistan to preside over a “graceful exit.”
articles.abstract: The commander of American and NATO forces said he did not come to Afghanistan to preside over a “graceful exit.”
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. David H. Petraeus, the commander of American and NATO forces, began a campaign on Sunday to convince an increasingly skeptical public that the American-led coalition can still succeed here despite months of setbacks, saying he had not come to Afghanistan to preside over a “graceful exit.”

articles.headline: Muscular ‘Expendables’ Enlivens Battle for Studio
articles.snippet: “The Expendables,” an ensemble action film starring and directed by Sylvester Stallone, took in an estimated $35 million in ticket sales and beat out “Eat Pray Love.”
articles.abstract: “The Expendables,” an ensemble action film starring and directed by Sylvester Stallone, took in an estimated $35 million in ticket sales and beat out “Eat Pray Love.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  After months of being chased by Carl C. Icahn, Lions Gate is chasing a box office hit.

articles.headline: Tapping the Web, 22,000 Miles Up
articles.snippet: Internet access via satellite tends to serve the underserved. With new technology, the providers hope to upgrade their service at lower cost.
articles.abstract: Internet access via satellite tends to serve the underserved. With new technology, the providers hope to upgrade their service at lower cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Satellite companies have been the also-rans of Internet providers.

articles.headline: Google Plan With Verizon Disillusions Some Allies
articles.snippet: Groups that saw Google as a top ally in the fight for net neutrality see its proposal with Verizon as a retreat.
articles.abstract: Groups that saw Google as a top ally in the fight for net neutrality see its proposal with Verizon as a retreat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  On Friday at lunchtime, as Google employees dined al fresco, a hundred protesters descended on the company’s Silicon Valley campus. A group called the Raging Grannies sang a song called “The Battle Hymn for the Internet,” and others carried signs reading, “Google is evil if the price is right.”
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Rates Fall as Market Fears Economic Weakness
articles.snippet: As governments try to bring down deficits, investors seem more concerned by the possibility of renewed recession.
articles.abstract: As governments try to bring down deficits, investors seem more concerned by the possibility of renewed recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: As 2010 began, there was nearly unanimous agreement in financial circles on at least one thing: Interest rates were sure to rise during the year.

articles.headline: China Passes Japan as Second-Largest Economy
articles.snippet: The move bolsters forecasts that China will surpass the U.S. as the world’s biggest economy as early as 2030.
articles.abstract: The move bolsters forecasts that China will surpass the U.S. as the world’s biggest economy as early as 2030.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  After three decades of spectacular growth, China passed Japan in the second quarter to become the world’s second-largest economy behind the United States, according to government figures released early Monday.

articles.headline: Workers Let Go by China’s Banks Are Putting Up a Fight
articles.snippet: Many employees who lost their jobs as state-run banks restructured are organizing to demand new jobs or compensation, but they face a daunting task.
articles.abstract: Many employees who lost their jobs as state-run banks restructured are organizing to demand new jobs or compensation, but they face a daunting task.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  These are heady days for China’s state-controlled banks. Last month, the Agricultural Bank of China made its stock market debut, bringing in $22 billion for the largest public offering ever. A sister government-run bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, now has the highest stock market value of any bank in the world.

articles.headline: Horror at Desert Ritual as Racer Flips Into Crowd
articles.snippet: An accident that killed eight has brought new attention to a form of recreation that has been criticized for its environmental harm and risks to humans.
articles.abstract: An accident that killed eight has brought new attention to a form of recreation that has been criticized for its environmental harm and risks to humans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUCERNE VALLEY, Calif.  They came at dusk, more than 1,000 fans driving pickups and off-road vehicles down eight miles of dirt road, to celebrate an annual rite of summer that draws an intensely loyal group of followers: night racing deep in the Mojave Desert by a fleet of souped-up trucks tackling a barely marked 40-mile track of rocks, ruts, sand and sagebrush.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Joseph Berger

articles.headline: Outdoors and Out of Reach, Studying the Brain
articles.snippet: Five scientists spent a week in the wilderness to understand how heavy use of technology changes how we think and behave.
articles.abstract: Five scientists spent a week in the wilderness to understand how heavy use of technology changes how we think and behave.
articles.lead_paragraph: GLEN CANYON NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, Utah  Todd Braver emerges from a tent nestled against the canyon wall. He has a slight tan, except for a slim pale band around his wrist.

articles.headline: Hulu Is Said to Be Ready for an I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Despite its status as a big player in online video, the company currently makes little in the way of profit.
articles.abstract: Despite its status as a big player in online video, the company currently makes little in the way of profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hulu, the rapidly growing hub for online television and movies, aims to go public through an offering that could value the company at more than $2 billion, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Floods Could Have Lasting Impact for Pakistan
articles.snippet: As officials struggle with immediate response to the disaster, concerns are growing about the toll on the overall economy, food supply and stability.
articles.abstract: As officials struggle with immediate response to the disaster, concerns are growing about the toll on the overall economy, food supply and stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan  Even as the government and international relief workers struggle to get food and clean water to millions of flood-stricken Pakistanis, concerns are growing about the enduring toll of the disaster on the nation’s overall economy, food supply and political stability.
